children.label: farms
children.definition: Any establishment that normally produces and sells agricultural products.

children.label: commercial farms
children.definition: farms which produce crops and livestock primarily for sale.

children.label: small farms
children.definition: Farms with less than $250,000 gross receipts annually, on which day-to-day labor and management are provided by the farmer and/or the farm family that owns the production or owns, or leases, the productive assets.

children.label: family farms
children.definition: An agricultural business which (1) produces agricultural commodities for sale in such quantities so as to be recognized as a farm rather than a rural residence; (2) produces enough income (including off farm employment) to pay family and farm operating expenses, to pay debts, and to maintain the property; (3) is managed by the operator; (4) has a substantial amount of labor provided by the operator and family; and (5) may use seasonal labor during peak periods and a reasonable amount of full-time hired labor.

children.label: cash grain farms
children.definition: A farm where corn, grain sorghum, small grains, soybeans, or field peas and beans account for at least 50% of the value of farm products sold.

children.label: food inspection
children.definition: Examination of foods to assure wholesome and clean products free from unsafe microbes or chemical contamination, natural or added deleterious substances, and decomposition during production, processing, packaging, etc.

children.label: physical control
children.definition: The management, eradication or exclusion of pests by nonchemical, abiotic methods or physical barriers.

children.label: disinfestation
children.definition: The application of any chemical, biological or physical procedures intended to eliminate undesired species (rodents, insects etc.).

children.label: biofumigation
children.definition: A fumigation technique for pest and disease control dependent upon the biocidal properties of natural fumigants released from such organisms as glucosinolate-containing plants.

children.label: pesticides
children.definition: A pesticide is any substance or mixture of substances intended for preventing, destroying, repelling, or mitigating any pest.

children.label: ovicides
children.definition: Chemical agents that kill the egg stage of a pest or parasite.

children.label: algicides
children.definition: Pesticides that control algae in lakes, canals, swimming pools, water tanks, and other sites.

children.label: larvicides
children.definition: Chemical agents that kill the larval stage of a pest or parasite.

children.label: silvicides
children.definition: A pesticide designed to kill unwanted woody plants.

children.label: chemosterilants
children.definition: A chemical that controls pests by preventing reproduction.

children.label: molluscicides
children.definition: Pesticides that kill snails and slugs.

children.label: blasticidin S
children.definition: A nucleoside antibiotic produced by Streptomyces griseochromogenes. It is a protein synthesis inhibitor in both prokaryltic and eukaryotic cells.

children.label: rodenticides
children.definition: Pesticides that are used for controlling mice and other rodents.

children.label: herbicides
children.definition: Pesticides that kill weeds and other plants that grow where they are not wanted.

children.label: monuron TCA
children.definition: Salt of monuron and trichloroacetic acid.

children.label: fenuron TCA
children.definition: Salt of fenuron and trichloroacetic acid.

children.label: mycoherbicides
children.definition: Formulations of plant pathogenic fungi which control the growth of or kill undesirable plants and weeds.

children.label: insecticides
children.definition: Pesticides that kill insects.

children.label: neonicotinoid insecticides
children.definition: The neonicotinoids are a class of insecticides with a common mode of action that affects the central nervous system of insects, causing paralysis and death.

children.label: sulfoxaflor
children.definition: Sulfoxaflor is a systemic insecticide within the sulfoxamine class of insecticides that is used for the management of a wide range of insect pests due to its high insecticidal activity. It acts on the insect nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (nAChR).

children.label: nematicides
children.definition: Pesticides that kill nematodes.

children.label: biopesticides
children.definition: Biopesticides are certain types of pesticides derived from such natural materials as animals, plants, bacteria, and certain minerals. For example, canola oil and baking soda have pesticidal applications and are considered biopesticides. Biopesticides fall into three major classes: 1. Microbial pesticides, 2. Plant-Incorporated-Protectants (PIPs) and 3. Biochemical pesticides.

children.label: microbial pesticides
children.definition: Microbial pesticides consist of a microorganism (e.g., a bacterium, fungus, virus or protozoan) as the active ingredient. Microbial pesticides can control many different kinds of pests, although each separate active ingredient is relatively specific for its target pest(s).

children.label: mycoherbicides
children.definition: Formulations of plant pathogenic fungi which control the growth of or kill undesirable plants and weeds.

children.label: acaricides
children.definition: A type of pesticide that kills or injures mites and ticks (acarides).

children.label: milbemycins
children.definition: Family of macrolide antibiotics with insecticidal & acaricidal activity. milbemectin is a mixture of milbemycins A3 and A4; structure in first source; moxidectin (CL 301,423) is milbemycin B.

children.label: adulticides
children.definition: Chemical agents that kill the adult stage of a pest or parasite.

children.label: integrated pest management
children.definition: A pest management strategy using a systematic approach in which pest populations are monitored to determine if and when control methods are required. Integrated pest management (IPM) uses biological, chemical, physical, cultural and/or genetic control methods in order to minimize pesticide use, reduce production costs, and protect the environment.

children.label: biological pest control
children.definition: Biological pest control mitigates agricultural pest damage by introducing or enhancing the population of pathogens, parasites or predators which prey upon the targeted pest. Biological control is often used in tandem with other pest management strategies, including physical control, cultural control and chemical controls.

children.label: sterile insect technique
children.definition: Method of insect control, utilizing sterilizing doses of radiation, in which sterile insects (usually males) are mass-released into the environment to compete with wild populations for mates.

children.label: disinfestation
children.definition: The application of any chemical, biological or physical procedures intended to eliminate undesired species (rodents, insects etc.).

children.label: sanitation
children.definition: The development and application of measures designed to promote health and prevent disease.

children.label: disease surveillance
children.definition: The collection, analysis, and communication of information for the purpose of disease prevention and control, especially applicable to infectious disease.

children.label: conventional tillage
children.definition: The traditional method of farming in which soil is prepared for planting by completely inverting it with a moldboard plow. Subsequent working of the soil with other implements is usually performed to smooth the soil surface. Bare soil is exposed to the weather for some varying length of time depending on soil and climatic conditions.

children.label: chiseling
children.definition: Breaking or loosening the soil, without inversion, with a chisel cultivator or chisel plow. A practice used for grassland or pasture renovation.

children.label: conservation tillage
children.definition: Any of several farming methods that provide for seed germination, plant growth, and weed control yet maintain effective ground cover throughout the year and disturb the soil as little as possible. The aim is to reduce soil loss and energy use while maintaining crop yields and quality. No-till is the most restrictive (soil-conserving) form of conservation tillage. Other practices include ridge-till, strip-till, and mulch-till.

children.label: stubble tillage
children.definition: A tillage system which retains a high percentage of crop residue on the soil surface, thereby reducing wind erosion.

children.label: no-tillage
children.definition: A system of planting crops without tilling the soil with a plow, disk, chisel, or other tillage implement.

children.label: interrow tillage
children.definition: Tillage between the rows of growing plants

children.label: fertigation
children.definition: Application of appropriate amount of fertilizers (dissolved form or suspended form) to the plants via irrigation water or through irrigation systems.

children.label: controlled traffic systems
children.definition: A practice where all tractor, harvester, seeder and other farm equipment wheels repeatedly use the same wheel tracks for every tillage, planting, spray and harvest operation needed during crop production.

children.label: mulches
children.definition: Any substance spread or allowed to remain on the soil surface to conserve soil moisture and shield soil particles from the erosive forces of raindrops and runoff.

children.label: live mulches
children.definition: Typically, plants that grow close to the ground and are sown or planted as an understory to the main crop. Live mulches protect the soil from erosion and minimally compete with the growth of the main crop.

children.label: irrigation
children.definition: Application of water to soil for the purpose of plant production.

children.label: flood irrigation
children.definition: An irrigation system in which a field is flooded to a depth of a few inches.

children.label: border irrigation
children.definition: An irrigation system for sloping land in which parallel levees are built and the area between

children.label: furrow irrigation
children.definition: A surface irrigation method in which water is run in small ditches or furrows, usually spaced closely together between crop rows or groups of rows.

children.label: basin irrigation
children.definition: An irrigation system in which a field or orchard is divided into basins which are filled with water.

children.label: drainage systems
children.definition: Manmade systems of furrows, ditches, tile drains, pipes, etc. which collect and remove water from a central location.

children.label: fertilizers
children.definition: Any organic or inorganic material of natural or synthetic origin which is added to soil to provide nutrients, including nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium, necessary to sustain plant growth.

children.label: composts
children.definition: Organic residues, or a mixture of organic residues and soil, which have been piled, moistened, and allowed to undergo biological decomposition for use as a fertilizer.

children.label: mushroom compost
children.definition: A specially formulated and processed compost usually containing manure, straw and other waste materials which is used in mushroom production.

children.label: compost extracts
children.definition: Liquid extracts of compost which may be used as a plant growth stimulator/fertilizer/insecticide or for plant disease control.

children.label: terracing
children.definition: In agronomic practice, the construction of ridges of earth built across a slope with a flat or graded channel to stop soil erosion and control the runoff of water.

children.label: agricultural land
children.definition: Land used primarily for the production of farm commodities. The categories of "agricultural land" are: cropland and pasture; orchards, groves, vineyards, bush fruits, and horticultural areas (such as nurseries); feeding operations; and other.

children.label: cropland
children.definition: Land used primarily for the production of adapted cultivated and close-growing crops for harvest, alone or in association with sod crops, and open land recently in such uses. In some states land in fruit and nut trees, grapes, etc., is designated orchard land or vineyard land rather than "cropland".

children.label: farm area
children.definition: The area of agricultural land used for farming (crop and livestock production).

children.label: pastures
children.definition: An area devoted to the production of forage (introduced or native) and harvested by grazing.

children.label: annual pastures
children.definition: A pasture consisting of introduced forage species planted for only one year or season's duration.

children.label: plantations
children.definition: Agricultural land, usually of large size, in which one or more major crop(s) or stand of plants (such as cotton, tobacco, sugar cane, oil palms, forest trees, etc.) is established either by sowing or planting.

children.label: forest plantations
children.definition: Forest stand regenerated artificially either by sowing or planting.

children.label: farming systems
children.definition: The farming system is defined as a decision-making unit comprising the farm household, cropping systems, and livestock systems, which transforms land, external inputs (seed, pesticides, nutrients, etc.), and labor (including knowledge) into useful products that can be consumed or sold.

children.label: alternative farming
children.definition: Production methods other than energy- and chemical intensive one-crop (monoculture) farming. Alternatives include using animal and green manure rather than chemical fertilizers, integrated pest management instead of chemical pesticides, reduced tillage, crop rotation (especially with legumes to add nitrogen), alternative crops, or diversification of the farm enterprise.

children.label: traditional farming
children.definition: The original farming method handed down from generation to generation. It involves the intensive use of indigenous knowledge, natural resources and cultural beliefs of the farmers.

children.label: agropastoralism
children.definition: The form of farming that combines crop production with extensive livestock rearing.

children.label: agrivoltaic systems
children.definition: Agrivoltaics is an arrangement of land use that collocates agriculture and solar photo-voltaic panels. This system helps in producing crops and electricity simultaneously from a single land unit.

children.label: low input agriculture
children.definition: A farming system in which the use of off-farm resources, such as commercially purchased chemicals and fuels, is minimized and the use of internal resources, such as biological pest controls, solar or wind energy, biologically fixed nitrogen, and other nutrients from green manures, organic matter or soil reserves, is maximized.

children.label: contour farming
children.definition: Field operations such as plowing, planting, cultivating, and harvesting on the contour, or at right angles to the natural slope, to reduce soil erosion, protect soil fertility, and use water more efficiently.

children.label: shifting cultivation
children.definition: A farming system, common in the tropics, in which land is cleared, the debris burned, and crops grown for a relatively short period until yields decline. The land is then abandoned. The original land is cleared and cropped again after a uncontrolled fallow period of 3-20 years, usually when soil fertility has been naturally restored by woody vegetation.

children.label: rainfed farming
children.definition: A system of producing crops without the use of irrigation.

children.label: extensive farming
children.definition: A system of raising crops and animals, usually on large parcels of land, where a comparatively small amount of production inputs or labor are used per acre. Compare intensive farming.

children.label: subsistence farming
children.definition: A farming system where the food and goods produced are predominantly consumed by the farm family and there is little surplus for sale in the market.

children.label: carbon farming
children.definition: A farming practice that sequester carbon.

children.label: precision agriculture
children.definition: A management strategy that utilizes site-specific information to precisely and economically manage and optimize production inputs.

children.label: intensive farming
children.definition: A system of raising crops and animals, usually on small parcels of land, where a comparatively large amount of production inputs or labor are used per acre. Compare extensive farming.

children.label: concentrated animal feeding operations
children.definition: A facility where large numbers of farm animals are confined, fed and raised such as cattle feedlots, hog production facilities and closed poultry houses.

children.label: sustainable agricultural intensification
children.definition: Sustainable crop production intensification provides opportunities for optimizing crop production per unit area, taking into consideration the range of sustainability aspects including potential and/or real social, political, economic and environmental impacts.

children.label: agroforestry
children.definition: An agroforestry system is a form of multiple land use where woody perennials (trees, shrubs, bamboos, palm trees, woody lianas) are grown on the same land management unit with crops and/or animals.

children.label: shade agroforestry systems
children.definition: An agroforestry system where the trees in the overstory provide shade to shade-loving crops growing in a lower strata, such as Vanilla growing on native timber species.

children.label: box planting
children.definition: A linear planting arrangement where the shape of the cultivated area is lined with woody perennials on the borders and crops.

children.label: forest farming
children.definition: Forest farming is the cultivation of high-value specialty crops under the protection of a forest canopy that has been modified to provide the correct shade level.

children.label: line planting (agroforestry)
children.definition: Woody perennials in a linear arrangement adjacent to cropland or grassland.

children.label: alley cropping
children.definition: A cropping system that involves growing crops in a wide strip, typically 6 meters in width, between lines of closely planted, fast-growing trees or shrubs. These woody species are usually leguminous and are pruned frequently to provide a mulching material and nutrients to the crop in the alley.

children.label: parkland agroforestry systems
children.definition: A type of agroforestry system in which large canopy trees are widely spaced in croplands or grasslands. The trees may be either planted or from natural regeneration.

children.label: multistrata agroforestry systems
children.definition: An agroforestry system whose components (crops, trees, shrubs, livestock, wildlife, etc.) occupy distinct layers of the vertical structure of the community. An example is the production of coffee intercropped with bananas occupying the lowest strata, shaded by medium-sized fruit trees in the middle vertical strata, with an overstory of tall timber trees in the upper canopy strata.

children.label: live fences
children.definition: A form of line planting meant for the demarcation and enclosure of a piece of cropland or pasture land.

children.label: taungya system
children.definition: A form of agroforestry system in which short term crops are grown in the early years of the plantation of a woody perennials species in order to utilize the land, control weeds, reduce establishment costs, generate early income and stimulate the development of the woody perennials species.

children.label: silvopastoral systems
children.definition: The combined use of forestland or woodland for both wood production and animal production by grazing of the coexisting indigenous forage, or vegetation that is managed like indigenous forage.

children.label: permaculture
children.definition: A system that develops agricultural systems modeled from natural ecosystems.

children.label: agropisciculture
children.definition: The practice of freshwater aquaculture with agriculture (crop production) concurrently or alternately.

children.label: dryland farming
children.definition: A system of producing crops in semiarid regions (usually with less than 20 inches of annual rainfall) without the use of irrigation. Frequently, part of the land will lie fallow in alternate years to conserve moisture.

children.label: pastoralism
children.definition: A way of life based on the raising and herding of livestock, such as sheep, goats, or horses.

children.label: transhumance
children.definition: Seasonal movement of livestock from one grazing area to another, such as movement of sheep from mountain pastures to lowland pastures.

children.label: agropastoralism
children.definition: The form of farming that combines crop production with extensive livestock rearing.

children.label: vertical farming
children.definition: Cultivation of vegetables, fruits, etc., vertically, within a building or other high rise structure, in a city or urban areas.

children.label: organic production
children.definition: A concept and practice of agricultural production that focuses on production without the use of synthetic inputs and does not allow the use of transgenic organisms. USDA's National Organic Program has established a set of national standards for certified organic production.

children.label: nutrient management
children.definition: Managing the amount, source, placement, form, and timing of the application of nutrients and soil amendments to ensure adequate soil fertility for plant production and to minimize the potential for environmental degradation, particularly water quality impairment.

children.label: cropping systems
children.definition: The pattern of crops grown on a given piece of land, or order in which the crops are cultivated over a fixed period.

children.label: mixed cropping
children.definition: The growing of several crops simultaneously in the same field but not in rows.

children.label: sequential cropping
children.definition: The growing of two or more crops in sequence on the same field in the same year.

children.label: intercropping
children.definition: Any pattern of planting a plant in or near other plants.

children.label: alley cropping
children.definition: A cropping system that involves growing crops in a wide strip, typically 6 meters in width, between lines of closely planted, fast-growing trees or shrubs. These woody species are usually leguminous and are pruned frequently to provide a mulching material and nutrients to the crop in the alley.

children.label: relay cropping
children.definition: The seeding of one crop into another standing crop, e.g., winter wheat into standing soybeans. A practice of starting one crop in another.

children.label: strip cropping
children.definition: The growing of crops in a systematic arrangement of strips or bands which serve as vegetative barriers to wind and water erosion. The strips or bands may run perpendicular to the slope of the land or to the direction of prevailing winds.

children.label: crop rotation
children.definition: System of cultivation where different crops are planted in consecutive growing seasons to maintain soil fertility.

children.label: double cropping
children.definition: Two different crops grown on the same area in one growing season.

children.label: sole cropping
children.definition: Growing one crop variety in pure stands on a piece of land at any one time.

children.label: ratooning
children.definition: Production of a subsequent crop that results from the regrowth from roots of the previous harvested crop, as in sugarcane, pineapple, and banana.

children.label: bioenergy cropping
children.definition: Growing crops for the production of bio-fuels.

children.label: continuous cropping
children.definition: The growing of a single crop species on a field year after year. Contrast crop rotation and mixed cropping.

children.label: sustainable agriculture
children.definition: An integrated system of plant and animal production practices having a site-specific application that will, over the long-term— (A) satisfy human food and fiber needs; (B) enhance environmental quality and the natural resource base upon which the agriculture economy depends; (C) make the most efficient use of nonrenewable resources and on-farm resources and integrate, where appropriate, natural biological cycles and controls; (D) sustain the economic viability of farm operations; and (E) enhance the quality of life for farmers and society as a whole.

children.label: community supported agriculture
children.definition: Community Supported Agriculture consists of a community of individuals who pledge support to a farm operation so that the farmland becomes, either legally or spiritually, the community's farm, with the growers and consumers providing mutual support and sharing the risks and benefits of food production.

children.label: good agricultural practices
children.definition: Guidelines and methods for farmers, growers, food producers, and those involved in agriculture to manage the resources important to agriculture, such as soil, water, and air, to produce safe and hygienic food products with commitment to sustainability and conservation, while protecting human and animal health and welfare as well as the environment.

children.label: sustainable agricultural intensification
children.definition: Sustainable crop production intensification provides opportunities for optimizing crop production per unit area, taking into consideration the range of sustainability aspects including potential and/or real social, political, economic and environmental impacts.

children.label: crop diversification
children.definition: Crop diversification is defined as the strategy of shifting from less profitable to more profitable crops, changing of variety and cropping system, increasing exports and competitiveness in both domestic and international markets, protecting the environment, and making conditions favorable for combining Agriculture-Fishery-Forestry-Livestock. Crop diversification can be a useful means to increase crop output under different situations.

children.label: precision agriculture
children.definition: A management strategy that utilizes site-specific information to precisely and economically manage and optimize production inputs.
